long-time exposure to VOCs, which could result in respiratory system diseases, skin irritations, and sick building syndrome. Additionally, gas sensing also plays a crucial part in fire detection, drug delivery, food safety, environmental monitoring, and national defense security.[1] Gas sensors based on organic field-effect transistors (OFETs), as one of the promising candidates among sensors based on electrical, optical[2] and acoustic mechanism, are interesting due to the inherent merits of low fabrication requirements, potential low cost, specific selectivity, and room temperature operation.[3] In general, an OFET architecture is composed of a gate electrode, a gate insulator or a dielectric layer, an active and sensing semiconductor layer, and source–drain electrodes, thus making up a typical three-terminal device.[4] Upon applying source–drain bias (VDS), carriers injected from the source electrode will transport along the organic semiconductor (OSC) sensing layer and form a conduction channel toward the drain electrode, and the charge carrier density and output
source–drain current (IDS) can be adjusted by gate bias (VGS) over repetitive increase. OSCs, acting as charge transporting layers and sensing materials, hold advantages like molecular tunability, light weight, solution processability, and mechanical flexibility. These advantages enable OFETs to acquire extensive research interest in a wide range of fields such as sensing chemical compounds,[5] light,[6] pressure,[7] temperature,[8] humidity,[9] and biological species.[10] OSCs are organic compounds that transport charges between molecules through conjugated π bonds. This charge transfer mode makes them susceptible to external environment and suitable for chemical sensors.[11] When the OSC sensing layer is exposed to external analyte stimuli, special interactions between the active layer and analytes will occur such as doping, quenching, and dipole effect. Such interactions will lead to the changes in charge carrier density, field-effect mobility, and other carrier transport properties, and then enable instant detection and response to the external analyte stimuli.[12]
By coupling the intrinsic merits of the sensitive materials and the OFET device structure, the signal transduction of the external stimuli and the signal amplification can be realized by one device simultaneously. Accurate measurements of the sensor characteristics can be obtained through the sensing parameters of field-effect mobility (µFET, a measure of the speed
Benefiting from the advantages of organic field-effect transistors (OFETs), including synthetic versatility of organic molecular design and environmental sensitivity, gas sensors based on OFETs have drawn much attention in recent years. Potential applications focus on the detection of specific gas species such as explosive, toxic gases, or volatile organic compounds (VOCs) that play vital roles in environmental monitoring, industrial manufacturing, smart health care, food security, and national defense. To achieve high sensitivity, selectivity, and ambient stability with rapid response and recovery speed, the regulation and adjustment of the nano/microstructure of the organic semiconductor (OSC) layer has proven to be an effective strategy. Here, the progress of OFET gas sensors with nano/microstructure is selectively presented. Devices based on OSC films one dimensional (1D) single crystal nanowires, nanorods, and nanofibers are introduced. Then, devices based on two dimensional (2D) and ultrathin OSC films, fabricated by methods such as thermal evaporation, dip-coating, spin-coating, and solution-shearing methods are presented, followed by an introduction of porous OFET sensors. Additionally, the applications of nanostructured receptors in OFET sensors are given. Finally, an outlook in view of the current research state is presented and eight further challenges for gas sensors based on OFETs are suggested.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Our society is undergoing a brand-new era due to rapid and sustained development of science and technology, along with revolutionary mode of production. Consequently, increasing concerns have been aimed at the deteriorating environmental issues, health care, and industrial safety where valid detection of explosive and toxic gases or volatile organic compounds (VOCs) being more and more important. Notably, intense research has proved that human health can be seriously threatened by

of the charge carrier movement along the sensing layer under electric field), threshold voltage (Vth, the turn-on voltage of the device), on/off current ratio (Ion/Ioff, the ratio of the on-state current to the off-state current between the source and drain electrodes), and subthreshold swing (SS, the parameter of qualification of how sharply the transistor is turned off by the gate voltage). Thus far, OFETs have received particular interest in the gas sensing field and further been expected to meet the core requirements of high sensitivity, selectivity, and high ambient stability with low concentration of detection limits (LOD).[6,13] Certainly, fast response and high recovery rate are also needed for practical applications. Traditional thick films usually exhibit limited sensitivity and selectivity with slow response and recovery speed. The conduction channel of OFETs is usually at the bottom of the semiconductor layer and charge carriers gather near the interface between the semiconductor and the dielectric layer. In order to further improve the sensitivity and response speed of the device, the key is to make the molecule interact with charge carriers more conveniently.[12b,14] However, bulk thick films usually hinder the charge carrier transport and gas diffusion. To address these issues, synthetic versatility of state-of-the-art protocols in tailoring the novel semiconductor functionalization and developing new fabrication techniques have been conducted within these years.[15] Recent reports have pointed out that regulation of OSC molecule structures and nano/microstructures of OSC films has been demonstrated impactful for constructing molecule-charge fast interaction channels and improving the device sensing performance. In order to enhance the sensitivity and increase the response and recovery speed, modification of the OSC layer is the most effective and straight forward approach. Relevant strategies commonly adopted include fabricating one dimensional (1D) nano/microstructured OSCs, modulating thickness of the OSC active layer within the scale of single molecular layer or a few monolayer layers, and preparing porous structures in OSC films, from the standpoint of the modification in the OSC morphology.[5b,16] Moreover, incorporation of functional groups and receptors into the surface of the OSC films endows OFET gas sensors with specific recognition ability and desirable sensing capacity to distinguish target analytes selectively.[10c,17]
OFET gas sensors have been extensively studied and reported. Considering the vital function of OSCs in the sensing process, our review focuses on selected progresses about OFET sensors with the modification and melioration of the OSC active layer with nano/microstructure.[10c] First of all, high-performance OFET gas sensors based on 1D singlecrystal nanowires, nanorods, and nanofibers will be introduced. Then, focus will be on the fabrication methods to obtain two dimensional (2D) and ultrathin OSC films, such as thermal evaporation, dip-coating, spin-coating, and solution-shearing methods, followed by an introduction of OFET gas sensors based on porous OSC structures. Additionally, the applications of functional receptors on top of OSC films and the resulted improvements on target analytes selectivity will be summarized. Hopefully, this review could provide readers with a clear cognition of recent progresses in OSC active layer modulation, to some extent, enlightening and carving a path for other researchers dedicated in the field of OFET gas sensors, thus advancing the development of their potential applications.
Shiqi Zhang received her Bachelor’s degree from the College of Nano Science and Technology of Soochow University. Now, she is pursuing her Doctor’s degree under the supervision of Prof. Jia Huang at Tongji University. Her current research interest is organic thin-film transistors and chemical sensors.
Jia Huang is a Professor of materials science and engineering at Tongji University in Shanghai, China. He received his B.Sc. in Materials Science and Engineering at the University of Science and Technology of China, his M.Sc. in Applied Science at the College of William & Mary, USA, and his Ph.D. in Materials Science
and Engineering at Johns Hopkins University, USA. Currently, Dr. Jia Huang’s research focuses on organic semiconductors, flexible electronics, thin-film transistors, and transistor-based sensors.

sections.heading: 2. 1D Nano/Microstructured OSCs
sections.text:
1D OFETs usually means OFETs with the semiconductor layers being 1D nano/micro materials such as nano- or microwires, rods, ribbons, and fibers. OFETs with single-crystal nano/ microstructured OSC layers represent one of the most widely investigated candidates for OFET gas sensors.[18] 1D structure can improve the sensitivity of OFETs due to the relative large surface-to-volume ratio. And the target gases can have fast access to the interface between the active layer and dielectric layer.[19] However, it is difficult to fabricate 1D structure with uniform morphology and quality,[20] so methods that can grow high-quality 1D single crystalline semiconductors remain a challenge.
For OFET sensors, decent electronic performance with sufficient high output current is needed for convenient measurement and practical applications. By utilizing 1D structure, the electronic performance of OFETs does not necessarily decline. Actually with desired fabrication process, it can even be improved compared to thin-film devices. Zhu et al. reported OFETs with self-assembly poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) nanowires, which had a length and width of 20–30 µm and 50 nm, respectively.[20b] Compared to P3HT thin-film OFETs, the µFET and Ion/Ioff of P3HT nanowire OFETs have been significantly improved due to the uniformly arranged nanowires, the value

of which can reach 0.06 cm2 V−1 s−1 and 104, respectively. The results indicate that high-performance OFETs can be achieved via 1D organic nanowire array. Due to effective and direct adsorption with the target gas, OFETs with 1D nano/ microstructured OSCs can have rapid interactions between the active layer and analytes, thus leading to a more sensitive response and a lower LOD for analytes than that of traditional films-based OFETs. Moreover, 1D OFETs are considered to be a more promising candidate for wearable devices, since they exhibit better flexibility for its lower dimensions than filmsbased OFETs. Guo et al. fabricated porphyrin nanoassemblies by surfactant-assisted assembly for hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) vapor sensing. Semiconductors 5,10,15,20-tetra(4pyridyl)-21H,23H-porphine (H2TPyP), zinc-5,10,15,20-tetra(4pyridyl)-21H,23H-porphine (ZnTPyP), and oxo-[5,10,15,20tetra(4-pyridyl)porphyrinato]titanium(IV) (TiOTPyP) were prepared, but only TiOTPyP could be fabricated into nanofiberbased gas sensors, which showed excellent sensing performance for H2O2 vapor detection.[20a] This could be accounted for the long straight nanofibers formed by TiOTPyP J-like aggregates, while only irregular aggregates and short nanorods were formed for H2TPyP and ZnTPyP. The gas sensors based on TiOTPyP presented percent current alternation of 2.1 × 104 upon exposure to 0.25 ppm H2O2. The response and recovery time were 2 and 25 s, respectively, which were obviously shorter than those of the thin-film-based devices (9 s for response time and 60 s for recovery time). Organic molecules with planar construction and large π–π conjugation are likely to form single crystals. Copper phthalocyanine (CuPc) is such a material that has been used to prepare 1D semiconductors. Shaymurat et al. have fabricated highly sensitive 1D CuPc OFET sensors for detecting sulfur dioxide (SO2). Physical vapor transport (PVT) and template method have also been investigated to grow 1D OSCs. The CuPc single crystalline nanowires were successfully synthesized via PVT and self-assembly process.[21] The LOD of this OFET for SO2 sensing was down to 0.5 ppm, which had a sensitivity of 119% ppm−1 (Figure 1c,d). Besides, the response and recovery time were 3 and 8 min for 0.5 ppm SO2, respectively. It was calculated that the trap density of the CuPc nanowire FETs and the CuPc thin film FETs was 1.3 × 1012 and 2 × 1012 cm−2 V−1. The sensing improvement can be attributed to higher surface-to-volume ratios and less traps in nanowire devices than thin-film devices in their report. Hu’s group prepared 1D OFETs for ethanol vapor detection.[22] Nano- and microcrystals of a pentacene analog indolo[3,2-b]carbazole,2,8dichloro-5,11-dihexy-lindolo[3,2-b]carbazole (CHICZ) nano- and microcrystals were synthesized via PVT. CHICZ was heated to ≈155 °C and then grew on the octadecyltrichlorosilane (OTS)modified SiO2/Si substrate into nano/micrometer-sized ribbons

at low temperature, whose length, width, and thickness were in ranges of 20–100 µm, 3–6 µm, and 30–80 nm, respectively, as shown in Figure 1e,f. And the ribbons were then fabricated into OFETs by a “organic ribbon mask” technique. The device exhibited decent transistor performance, with µFET value of 0.8 cm2 V−1 s−1. The Ion/Ioff ratio of the OFET was as high as 1.7 × 107, and the Vth value was −7.3 V. As shown in Figure 1g,h, the 1D OFET presented good sensitivity and reproducibility to the detection of ethanol gas. Mun et al. carried out a comprehensive work based on single-crystal P3HT nanowires (Figure 1i,j).[23] The P3HT nanowires were prepared by a liquidbridge-mediated nanotransfer molding (LB-nTM) method. Afterwards, P3HT nanowires were printed on the hard molds and then transferred onto the SiO2/Si substrate with ethanol layer forming the active layer. Finally, silver source and drain electrodes were deposited on the active layer by thermal evaporation through a shadow mask. Benefiting from 1D nanostructure of the P3HT nanowires, the fabricated OFET demonstrated three times more sensitive ammonia (NH3) detection than the P3HT thin film OFET, with a LOD of 0.01 ppm (Figure 1k,l).
Although 1D OSCs can significantly improve the sensing performance of OFET chemical sensors, the uniformity is a big issue. The number, diameter, and length of nanowires contained between different samples usually differ greatly, resulting in significant diversity in device performance of different batches, and their practical applications will be affected severely. However, as for the OFET based on 2D structure and traditional thin films, the problem is relatively less serious.

sections.heading: 3. 2D and Ultrathin OSC Films
sections.text:
The active OSC layer plays a vital role in both charge transport and sensing process of OFET sensors. Not merely the analyte molecules adsorption, but also the interactions between analytes and semiconductors occur in the active layer. It is acknowledged that the charge carrier conduction channel is close to the interface between the OSC film and the dielectric layer, usually at the bottom of the OSC layer. Therefore, the thickness of the OSC layer has substantial impact on the OFET gas sensor sensitivity and response speed. A thinner OSC layer can lead to a more exposed conduction channel, and hence reduce the diffusion length of the analytes in OSC before they can interact with charges in the conduction channel, compared to a thick OSC film. Thus, OFET chemical sensors with ultrathin OSC layers, at the thickness of a few molecular layer, or even single molecular layer, can have significantly improved sensing performance.
A number of techniques have been put forward to fabricate ultrathin OSC films, such as thermal evaporation,[24] spin-coating,[24e,25] bar-coating,[26] spray-coating, dip-coating,[27] drop-casting, inkjet printing, blade coating,[28] self-assembly,[29] and Langmuir–Blodgett methods.[30] As for small-molecule OSCs, high-vacuum thermal evaporation is a commonly used fabrication technique. A well-controlled temperature and a high-vacuum level are necessary for the fabrication of highquality ultrathin films with low-density defects. With such a method, OSC films can be deposited layer by layer molecularly, while the solution-processed methods lack precise control of the thickness and nanostructure of films. Katz and co-workers carried out systematic work on the impact of organic film thickness modulation of 5,5′-bis-(4-hexylphenyl)-2,2′-bithiophene (6PTTP6) on the performance of OFET gas sensor upon exposure to dimethyl methylphosphonate (DMMP) nerve agent stimulant vapor.[31] As illustrated in Figure 2a, the effect of film thickness of 6PTTP6 on the film morphology and µFET has been studied thoroughly, and the results indicate that the mobility would undergo a sharp transition to a saturated regime when the film thickness increased from sub-monolayers to several monolayers. Compared to the conventional thick film, the ultrathin 1.31 monolayer 6PTTP6 film started to exhibit prominent transistor behaviors. Moreover, the OFET sensor based on the ultrathin film (Figure 2b) exhibited faster response speed and higher sensitivity than that of conventional devices. Another work exploiting the vacuum-evaporation fabrication method for ultrathin OSC film was reported by Jiang’s group.[32] They successfully grew ultrathin pentacene films within 1–3 monolayers (Figure 2c) and achieved much higher response to NH3 than the conventional OFET sensor based on a 50 nm thick pentacene film (Figure 2d). Yan’s group reported a high-performance NO2 gas sensor based on a highly ordered organic ultrathin heterojunction film.[33] The sensor device configuration is represented in Figure 2e. An accumulated heterojunction consisting of 1 nm thick N,N′diphenylperylenetetracarboxylic diimide (PTCDI-Ph) film and 5 nm thick para-hexaphenyl (p-6P) film was prepared. These films were not highly sensitive to NH3 separately. A highly ordered heterojunction was formed by epitaxially growing PTCDI-Ph on the surface of the p-6P ultrathin film. The heterojunction film tended to have a smoother surface with larger domains than the ordinary single PTCDI-Ph layer. The introduction of the heterojunction structure caused the accumulation of electrons and holes within the interface, thus leading to the Ohmic behavior and increasing the conductivity by two orders of magnitude value higher than that of those singlelayer devices (Figure 2f). The combination of ultrathin film and heterojunction can improve the charge-carrier transport in the film, and then enhance the electronic signal produced in devices. Moreover, the ultrathin film can shorten the time of gas diffusion and result in quicker response and recovery rate. Also, the heterojunction between PTCDI-Ph and p-6P makes the system more sensitive to NO2 gas and ultrasensitive to out stimulus. Further on, a double heterojunction was constructed with a highly sensitive vanadyl phthalocyanine (VOPc) layer at the top of the PTCDI-Ph film (Figure 2g), which significantly improved the sensitivity to gas by five times compared to that of the single-heterojunction devices. These results suggest that the combination of ultrathin film and heterojunction can improve the sensitivity of OFET gas sensors.[34] Chi’s group have fabricated nitrogen dioxide (NO2) sensors based on a high-quality crystalline 6,13-bis(triisopropylsilylethynyl)pentacene (TIPS-Pentacene) film by thermal deposition (Figure 2h). Figure 2i,j illustrates the dynamic response of a 7.5 nm TIPSPentacene/p-6p sensor device with various NO2 concentrations, which shows an ultrahigh sensitivity exceeding 1000% ppm−1 at several ppm and a calculated LOD of 20 ppb.[35] In addition, this work provided a comprehensive discussion on the relationship between the charge transport and the sensor performance

Despite the advantages of thermal evaporation method benefitting high-quality films with low-density defects, the need of high vacuum and the slow processing speed result in high fabrication cost. In addition, polymer semiconductors can only be prepared by solution process instead of thermal evaporation. In this sense, solution-processable methods have emerged into researchers’ sight,[7,17b,36] due to the advantages in vacuumfree process, low fabrication cost, and high scalability. The film thickness can be adjusted from nanometers to micrometers by alerting the solution concentration, angular velocity, and spinning duration. Zhu’s group employed a simple and convenient method known as “on-the-fly-dispensing-spincoating” to fabricate ultrathin polymer semiconductor films.[37]

The fabrication process of the ultrathin film is illustrated in Figure 3a. By modifying solution concentration and rotation speed, precise thickness control of OSC films can be achieved. This technique has been applied in producing ultrathin films consisting of few layers (≤5 layers) down to a monolayer, including NDI3HUDTYM2, NDI(2OD)(4tBuPh)-DTYM2, poly[2,5-bis(3-alkylthiophen-2-yl) thieno(3,2-b)thiophene] (PBTTTC12), and P3HT. As for NH3 gas sensing (Figure 3b), the NDI(2OD)(4tBuPh)-DTYM2-based ultrathin film device exhibited higher sensitivity and more rapid response in comparison with the conventional thick film (70 nm) device. The simple spin-coating approach allows precise thickness control for a variety of OSCs with low defect density. Under high rotation rate, the tangential force breaks the static wetting balance on the hydrophobic substrate and successful deposition of ultrathin films is generated. Then, another effective and simple approach named wire-bound bar-coating method has also been put forward to deposit ultrathin polymer films with precise film thickness control. Noh’s group studied and demonstrated this technique to fabricate ultrathin OFET gas sensors.[26]

The ultrathin OFET sensors employed a p-channel polymer and an n-channel polymer, respectively. As shown in Figure 3c, the polymer ink was coated onto the substrate with the coating bar moving horizontally, and then dried from the edge to center. By tuning the solution concentration, coating speed, and the size of the wound-wire, various thicknesses of the conjugated polymer films could be simply obtained. Coating speed and the size of the wound-wire were fixed at values of 10 mm s−1 and 70 µm, respectively. More accurate experiments were conducted by changing the solution concentration from 10 to 1 mg mL−1, so that the film thickness could be adjusted as the p-channel polymer film varying from 12.8 (±1.0) nm down to 2.2 (±0.3) nm and the n-channel polymer film varying from 20.5 (±1.1) nm to 1.7 (±0.4) nm. As an example, the p-channel polymer film–based OFET sensor of film thickness lower than 2 nm showed a high sensitivity of 82% to NH3, while that for the 5.0 (±0.5) nm and 12.8 (±1.0) nm films was 27% and 10% (Figure 3d,e), respectively. It is obvious that thinner films based OFET sensors show higher sensitivity than sensors based on thick films. The work demonstrated the application of the wirebound bar-coating method in fabricating ultrathin polymer films. However, there are still remaining problems in this fabrication method, such as the lack of sufficient controllability, low repeatability, and reproducibility compared to vacuum evaporated films.
Though solvents evaporate more slowly as compared with high-speed evaporation in spin-coating methods, drop coating and drop casting can also produce highly crystalline films. During the dip-coating process, a substrate is dipped into the target solution vertically and then pulled out at a controlled speed. Chi’s group reported a series of progresses in fabricating ultrathin and continuous OSC films with microstripes in recent several years.[38] By varying the pulling speed, the facile growth of well-aligned monolayer to multilayer microstripes of a tetrathieno analog of pentacene (DTBDT-C9) can be precisely controlled with a large coverage area. The higher the speed is, the greater number of multilayers are. In 2013, they reported an NH3 gas sensor with dentritic microstripes of solution-processable dialkyl tetrathiapentacene (DTBDT-C6) (Figure 3f). The gas sensor of the OSC with 4–6 molecular layers possessed enhanced sensing performance due to its higher sensitivity, faster response and reversible time compared to thick-film devices (Figure 3g,h).[38b] Moreover, they demonstrated that this kind of growth method could be applicable in fabricating many other soluble OSCs. More recently, an unprecedented sensitivity (≈160% ppm−1) toward NH3 gas detection was observed by the same kind of OSC DTBDT-C6 microstripes with a film thickness as low as 2 nm. Through dipping and lifting the substrates at a fast rate in DTBDT-C6/toluene solution, the microstripes can be fast patterned within ultrathin film site selectively growing on the gold electrodes on OTS-modified substrate surfaces. It is reported that the thickness and stripe size had a strong dependence on the evaporation condition, because the microstripes evaporating in toluene vapor had an average thickness and width of 9 nm and 20 µm, respectively, while the microstripes evaporating in air had an ultrathin film thickness of only 2 nm. Based on microstripes evaporating in air, well orientated and ultrathin film could be fabricated. Then, the OFET sensors could respond to NH3 gas in 50–60 s and
recover in about 250 s, which was starkly contrast to those with microstripes evaporating in toluene (response and recovery time were 80–90 and 450–500 s, respectively).
Furthermore, as another feasible technique to produce highly crystalline and aligned organic crystals over a large area, solution-shearing method has been explored to fabricate highperformance solution-processable small-molecule films. One of the early demonstrations of this method in OFET chemical sensor applications was the fabrication of large-area and ultrathin films of 1,4-bis((50-hexyl-2,20-bithiophen-5-yl)ethynyl) benzene (HTEB) by utilizing solution-shearing technique (Figure 4a,b).[39] There are several important factors affecting the film morphology such as substrate surfaces, categories of solvents, solution concentration, temperature, and shearing speed. As depicted in Figure 4c,d, the ultrathin HTEB-based OFET sensor showed excellent sensitivity, high selectivity, and reversibility to NH3 gas, with a LOD of 100 ppb. In another work, Chan and his co-workers developed a dual solutionshearing method to generate large-area, highly crystallized, and continuous semiconductors monolayers of 2,9-didecyldinaphtho [2,3-b:2′,3′-f ]thieno[3,2-b]thiophene (C10-DNTT) in millimeter scale.[40] The growth of crystallized semiconductor monolayer includes process of dissolving and recrystallization (Figure 4e). As shown in Figure 4f, the high-quality 4 nm monolayer film of C10-DNTT was achieved by controlling the concentration of semiconductor in the solvent, substrate deposition temperature, and shearing speed during the process of the two steps of solution shearing. The fabricated film exhibited the high mobility of up to 10.4 cm2 V−1 s−1, with an average value of 5.8 cm2 V−1 s−1. Outstanding sensing performance to NH3 (Figure 4g) with a LOD as low as 10 ppb was also obtained.

sections.heading: 4. OSC Films with 3D Porous Structure
sections.text: The porous structure, which endows gas sensors with a LOD and high sensitivity, has been applied in OFET gas sensors in the last few years. With the porous structure, analyte molecules can diffuse directly through nano/micropores to the conduction channel without the obstruction of thick and continuous OSC films. Herein, several effective approaches for fabricating porous OSC films to improve the performance of gas sensors are provided.

sections.heading: 4.1. Versatile Template Method
sections.text:
Template method utilizes model to regulate the OSC film morphology. Compared with hard template method, versatile template method can be adjusted according to the required product, which provides an effective and simple way to fabricate OSC films with controllable pore sizes. Lu et al. group reported an ammonia (NH3) gas sensor based on OFETs incorporating with microporous OSC films, which utilized a simple vacuum freeze-drying template method.[41] Dinaphtho[2,3b:2′,3′-f ]thieno-[3,2-b]thiophene (DNTT) as OSC was thermally evaporated on the substrate, before which polystyrene (PS) microspheres were deposited as a template. The optical images of the film with PS spheres and the film with micropores

formed by removal of PS are shown in Figure 5a,b. The schematic diagram (Figure 5c) shows that the porous structure provides pathway for analytes to diffuse into the conduction channel directly. As a result, the porous OFETs show a relative sensitivity of 340% ppm−1 upon exposure to 10 ppb NH3. Figure 5d presents that the current of porous OFET decreases 13% for 0.1 ppm with gate voltage (VG) fixed at −10 V, while the pristine one shows only 3.5% current decrease. As shown in Figure 5e, real-time responses of pristine and porous gas sensors also exhibited great difference to various low NH3 concentrations. All the electronic performances above show that the porous OFET exhibits higher sensitivity and shorter response time than the pristine one. Similarly, Yang and co-workers employed 200 nm diameter PS spheres as shadow mask and the PS spheres were left on the pentacene layer without damaging the operation of the device.[42] The PS spheres with a larger magnitude than the active layer formed gaps of around 10–30 nm width between themselves and pentacene layer. Then, the analyte can easily contact with the conduction channel through these sidewalls of the pentacene film. The absolute current variation ratios ΔI/I0 of this porous sensor was 5% to ammonia gas with a LOD of 500 ppb caused by the presence of pores.
These results proved that the pores in the active layer indeed improved devices’ sensitivity and response speed. Kang et al. also reported porous pentacene OFETs fabricated by a negative template method.[43] The underlying template m-bis(triphenylsilyl) benzene (TSB3) layer strongly altered the morphology of the active layer (pentacene). The OFET
structure is presented in Figure 5f. The high-quality film with obscure crystal boundaries resulted from the quasi-2D growth induced by an appropriate interaction energy between organic surface and small molecule, which was on account for the high µFET of pentacene OFETs. The pentacene OFETs with TSB3 had µFET of 5.5 (±0.7) cm2 V−1 s−1, which was higher than that of OFETs without TSB3, 1.5 (±0.2) cm2 V−1 s−1. According to their simulations, pentacene molecules preferred to deposit on the TSB3 surface instead of OTS layer, as shown in Figure 5g, to form porous films. Figure 5h exhibits the output current of sensors with TSB3 in terms of time, which decreases obviously under the exposure to methanol vapor. The devices exhibited short response and recovery time, as well as stable sensing behavior. The above methods provide new ways to fabricate semiconducting layers with improved sensing performances in terms of both sensing speed and sensitivity, without the reducing device stability.

sections.heading: 4.2. Blending Method
sections.text:
The fabrication process mentioned above involved the deposition and removal of the template. Another simple method to achieve porous structure film is to blend OSCs with additives such as insulating polymers.[44] The blending method not only simplifies the experimental procedures but also saves expensive OSCs materials, which is essential for the low-cost and largescale applications. Wu and co-workers fabricated films with adjustable pore sizes via spin-coating the blend of PBIBDF-BT

conjugated-polymer semiconductor and insulating poly(1,4butylene adipate) (PBA) (Figure 6a,b).[45] The fabrication process is presented in Figure 6c. Due to the immiscibility of the semiconductor PBIBDF-BT and the PBA, a phase separation occurred during the spin-coating process and the pore size was adjusted by controlling the contents of PBA in the compound mixture. After removing PBA by using acetone, a fibrous network structure was formed, as shown in Figure 6d; the carrier mobility µ value of the film with W20% PBA is higher than that of the neat film (0 wt% PBA) as shown in Figure 6e, f. However, as PBA increases, the channel area gets smaller, possibly resulting in the decrease of charge mobility. Vth in terms of PBA contents shows a negative shift for the hole-conduction (Figure 6g) while it increases for the electron-conduction (Figure 6h), which might be caused by the grain defects in the film. Figure 6i shows the transfer characteristics with VDS fixed at −80 V and output curves with VGS = −35 V when the device was exposed to NH3 of various concentrations (from 0 to 50 ppm). This sensor platform exhibited a LOD of 0.5 ppm, sensitivity of more than 800% ppm−1, and short response/recovery time within a few seconds. The cycle test under the same condition of the sensors based on continuous films are also presented in Figure 6k. It is obvious that the sensors with microporous films showed better performance than devices based on continuous films, judging from the response time, recovery time, and sensitivity, as shown in Figure 6l. Additionally, good stability was confirmed by the excellent reproducibility when devices had been stored in air environment for about one month (Figure 6j). Katz and his co-workers also developed a sensing platform for ethylene detection, inducing pores in the semiconductor layer (P3HT) by using N-(tert-butoxycarbonyloxy)-phthalimide as additive, which increased the overall sensing sites.[46] The sensitivity of the sensor was about 25 ppm V/V and the response was reversible. This investigation suggests that using blend of OSCs and insulating additives is an effective and low-cost approach to fabricate gas sensors with porous structures. The pores fabricated by blending method in the above literatures are nonuniform, with their sizes ranging from 50 to 500 nm regulated by the component ratio of the blend. The detection performance is further influenced by the noncontrollability of the pores. In this sense, Diao and co-workers demonstrated solution-processed tunable nanoporous OSC thin films where the pore sizes can be tuned in the insulating layer template.[47] As depicted in Figure 7a, meniscus-guided unidirectional coating (left, top) and spin-coating (left, bottom) are used, which are suitable for large-scale preparation. The tunable and relatively uniform pores in the template layer ranging from 50 to 700 nm shown in Figure 7b–e were acquired by altering the ratio of 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)diphthalic anhydride (HDA):poly(4-vinylphenol) (PVP). The DPP2T-TT and C8-BTBT semiconductors were deposited on the template as the active layer for ammonia and formaldehyde detection, respectively. Figure 7f shows the typical transfer curves of the OFETs with pores and without pores, with comparable electronic performance. The dynamic current responses of sensors anchored in DPP2T-TT for detecting NH3 is shown in Figure 7g. The read-out signals for low concentration of 1 ppb in Figure 7h indicated that the sensitivity was improved

The enhanced sensor performance is hypothesized to be attributed to the reactive sites exposed to volatile compounds (Figure 7i). It is vital to accurately control the pore size since the change of the current was found to be closely related with the pore size (Figure 7j). That is, the ΔI/I0 values of the sensors scale linearly with the pore wall area fraction (Areapore wall/Areatotal surface), according to Figure 7k. A small molecular semiconductor C8BTBT was also used to fabricate nanoporous OFET sensors for detecting formaldehyde, demonstrating the validity of this approach. Therefore, the incorporating of porous structures can effectively enhance the overall performance of gas sensors. The porous layers have not only formed the fast pathways for analyte– charge interaction, but also enhanced the gas capture ability of gas sensors.

sections.heading: 5. OSCs Films with Nano/Micro Scale Receptors
sections.text:
For OFET gas sensors, selectivity is an important parameter in addition to sensitivity. However, due to the similar mechanism
that analyte vapors interact with the active layer, OFETs tend to show low selectivity for various gases that have similar chemical properties or dipole moments.[3a,17b,48] Thus, strategies for improving the selectivity of OFETs remain a great challenge; yet, there are two methods that are usually applied. One is covalent modification of the semiconductor layer, and another is deposition of receptor layers to act as the host of the analyte. The former strategy may have a negative effect on the electronic performance of semiconductors, resulting in low output current.[4b] Therefore, the latter has attracted much attention in recent years.
As to receptors, several requests should be taken into consideration in order to fabricate OFETs with high sensitivity and selectivity. First, receptors should have as little side effect as possible on the electronic properties of the semiconductor layers. They should also fit in with the semiconductor layer with little hindrance for analyte/charge interaction and transport. Taking this into consideration, nanometer scale ultra-thin, molecular layer, or even sub-monolayer receptor layers would be desired. Second, the receptors should have a preference for capturing the target analytes selectively. Third, the receptors should be easy to be processed, by methods such as thermal

vapor deposition and solution processing on the semiconductor layer. In other words, it would be better if receptors have low sublimation temperature or good solubility. Last but not least, the receptors should be stable in the detection environment and can be reused for many times.
In order to effectively capture the target analytes, it is important to optimize the design of molecular structures of receptors. Molecular structures with cage or cup shapes are promising candidates to be incorporated into OFET receptors. As two particular interesting examples, cucurbituril and calixarene have a preferred absorption to certain gases and their target selectivity can be modulated via modification of the cavity size.[49] Cucurbituril-based molecules are a series of receptors that have five to eight repeated macrocycle units to form the cavities with different sizes. The more the repeated units it has, the larger the cavity it may form. Cucurbituril-based molecules with five, six, seven, and eight repeated units are called as cucurbit[5]uril, cucurbit[6]uril, cucurbit[7]uril, and cucurbit[8] uril, respectively. With the carbonyl at the portal of cucurbituril, cations tend to form complexes via ion–dipole interaction. The inner cavity of cucurbituril contains the alkyl chains, which can form strong binders between molecules, thus making cucurbituril hydrophobic. The cavity sizes of cucurbituril can be modulated by changing the repeated units. Complementarity of ion–dipole binding, hydrophobic effects, and cavity sizes between the analyte and cucurbituril determines whether cucurbituril can act as a high-quality receptor or not.[50] Jang et al. reported high-performance OFETs with perallyloxyCB[6] ((allyloxy)12CB[6],AOCB[6]) (Figure 8a) as the receptor that showed a specific response to the acetylcholine(ACh+).[51] The receptor AOCB[6] was first dissolved into methanol and the resulted solution was spin-coated on 5,5′-bis-(7-dodecyl9Hfluoren-2-yl)-2,2′-bithiophene (DDFTTF) and finally evaporated to form a thin film. The OFETs showed high selectivity
to ACh+ and outstanding stability in water. Devices showed response to ACh+ down to 1 × 10−12 m and discriminate between ACh+ and choline (Ch+) (Figure 8b,c). The sensing mechanism of AOCB[6] is that the charge–dipole interaction between positively charged methyl of ACh+ and negatively charged carboxyl of AOCB[6] has induced ACh+ into AOCB[6]. In another study, Jang et al. modified cucurbit[7]uril with two different functionalities and solution-processed this material on a DDFTTF semiconductor layer (Figure 8d).[49b] This OFET had a high sensitivity to amphetamine hydrochloride and methamphetamine hydrochloride, which could be detected even at a low concentration of 1 pm (Figure 8e,f). Although receptors discussed above were used for liquid detection, similar mechanism would also work for OFET gas sensors. It would be interesting to study their applications for gas sensors.
Similar to cucurbituril, calixarene is also a molecule with a cup-like structure and hydrogen bonds in the portal of the molecule. The cup-like structure forms the cavity that can trap desired gases, thus improving the sensitivity of OFETs. Moreover, the hydrogen binds around the rim of “cup” to form strong interactions with analytes. The cooperation between the cavity size and hydrogen bond contributes to the high selectivity of OFETs with calixarene as the receptor. Lee et al. developed solvent-resistant OFETs.[52] The cross-linked P3HT-azide acted as the semiconductor layer and calix[8]arene(C[8]A) (Figure 9e) acted as the receptor. Due to the special cross-linked structure, the OFETs could remain stable even in a liquid environment. The C[8]A improved the selectivity of OFET; compared to OFET without C[8]A, the OFET with C[8]A showed one order of magnitude higher sensitivity in methanol detection (Figure 9f) and exhibited various responses to methanol, ethanol, DI water, toluene, and n-hexane gases (Figure 9g). Sokolov et al. utilized C[8]A and C-methylcalix(4)-resorcinarene (CM[4]RA) as the receptor for gas detection, as shown in Figure 9a–c,

and the OFETs with the receptors showed obviously enhanced performance.[49a] The OFET modified by C[8]A exhibited a strong response to ethyl acetate at the concentration of 200 ppm (Figure 9d), while for OFET with pure DDFTTF, there was little response until the concentration reached 1000 ppm.
Introducing various special functionalities into receptors is another strategy to improve the selectivity of OFETs. Interactions such as hydrogen bond, charge–dipole interactions, and π–π interaction between receptors and analyte gases are the main mechanism behind.[3a] Modifying the receptor molecules can improve the procession abilities and make it easier to deposit on the semiconductor layers. Song et al. fabricated OFETs with dinaphtho[3,4-d:3′,4′-d′]benzo[1,2-b:4,5-b′]dithiophene (Ph5T2)-modified CuPc nanowires for the detection of NO2 and hydrogen sulfide (H2S). Compared with CuPc OFET without Ph5T2 modification, OFETs with Ph5T2 showed enhanced response to oxidizing gas like NO2 and decreased response to reducing gas like H2S.[53] It was suggested that the difference in responses of different analytes was due to the heterojunctions forming between CuPc and Ph5T2. Charge carriers could be modulated via heterojunctions. In an early study, Huang et al. developed a layer-bylayer OFET with 3 nm 6PTTP6 as the charge transport semiconductor and 3 nm 6PTTP6 blended with hydroxyhexyloxy analog (HO6OPT) as the receptor layer (Figure 10a,b).[24e] The OFET showed high sensitivity and selectivity to dinitrotoluene (DNT) vapor (Figure 10c). See et al. constructed a bilayer OFET, within which N-type N,N′-bis(1H,1H-perfluorooctyl) naphthalene-1,4,5,8-tetracarboxylicdiimide (F15-NTCDI) acted as the semiconductor layer and PHOH-NTCDI acted as the receptor for successful DMMP detection at 300 ppm.[54] Huang et al. developed a NH3 sensor anchored on an OFET with tris(pentafluorophenyl)borane (TPFB) as the receptor (Figure 10d).[55] The OFET had a 33% IDS decrease for CuPc
as the semiconductor and a 37% IDS decrease for cobalt phthalocyanine (CoPc) as the semiconductor (Figure 10e). The LOD could be as low as 0.35 ppm for NH3. The result was consistent with the strong host–guest interaction between TPFB and NH3, which contributed to the absorption of NH3 to the semiconductor surface. Shi et al. developed a high-performance NO2 gas sensor with pentacene as the semiconductor and guanine as the receptor (Figure 10f).[56] The LOD could be down to 1 ppm. Compared with the pure pentacene, pentacene–guanine bilayer OFET showed enhanced sensitivity and selectivity for NO2. Meanwhile, when exposed to other gases such as IPA, acetone, ethyl acetate, water, and acetic acid, OFET with guanine showed opposite or different magnitudes of responses, which implied sensing selectivity (Figure 10g,h).
Chemical reaction is another simple but effective way to absorb the target gas. Zang et al. utilized NH3 vapor as a special receptor to selectively detect HCl vapor (Figure 10i).[5a] The initial OFET with NDI(2OD)(4tBuPh)-DTYM2 or pentacene as the active layer showed little response to HCl even though 1000 ppm of HCl was injected. However, when NH3 vapor first flowed over the OFET and then the OFET was exposed in the HCl vapor environment, the OFET showed significantly enhanced sensitivity and selectivity to HCl even at 10 ppm, which resulted in 34% decrease of IDS. Interestingly, from ten successive cycles of sensing curves, they deduced that this NH3-based OFET could work steadily for several hundreds to thousands of time. The decreased IDS was on account of the electrostatic attractions generated when the absorbed NH3 contacted HCl airflow (Figure 10j,k).
The previous studies suggested that, the sensing properties can be enhanced effectively by utilization of receptors. However, when the target substances coexist with interference gases with similar structures and chemical properties, the selectivity of the OFET sensors based on single OSC layers is still not

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion and Outlook
sections.text:
After years of intensive development, gas sensors based on OFETs have gained sustained improvements and tremendous progresses in the effective detection of different ambient and toxic gases or VOCs. Compared to their counterparts, the OFET gas sensors exhibit advantages in terms of low power consumption, room temperature operability, and real-time portable sensing, and show great potentials in the field of environmental monitoring, food storage, fire detection, drug delivery, and smart health care. Our review focuses on recent progress of fabrication techniques in the modification and melioration of the OSC active layer with nano/microstructure. Strategies mostly adopted include fabricating 1D materials such as nanocrystals, nanowires, nanorods, and nanofibers, 2D ultrathin organic films, molecular receptors with versatility, and the porous structures within the interface of OSC films. Therefore, it is highly possible that, with advanced nano/microstructured morphology control and molecular functional design, a variety of practical gas sensing
applications can be realized in the future, with fascinating features such as high selectivity and specificity, high ambient stability, high reproducibility, fast response speed, low concentration of detection limit, and superior real-time portable workability.
Nowadays, to realize mature practical applications with low cost and enhanced stability, challenges still lie ahead. Further efforts are urgently needed: (1) More investigation should be executed to deeply comprehend the fundamental mechanism behind how diverse analytes impact the charge carrier generation, transport, and sensing behaviors, especially at those interfaces between electrode and semiconductor (charge injection area), dielectric layer and semiconductor (conduction channel), and grain boundaries. Since charge carriers concentrate in the bottom of OSC molecular layers in OFETs, for an OFET sensor with a thick active layer, the response speed and sensitivity will be limited, due to the relatively non-sensitive top molecular layers. Thus, the sensing performance will be highly dependent on the active layer thickness. For the semiconductor/dielectric interface effect, the impact on the sensing performance is not highly dependent on the thickness of the OSC layer. It would be useful to utilize both mechanisms simultaneously to optimize the sensing performance. (2) The study on the impact of contact resistance on sensing performance, and the mechanism about
Small 2019, 1805196
1805196 (15 of 16)
www.advancedsciencenews.com
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
www.small-journal.com
charge injection energy barrier for OFET chemical sensors, is still quite limited and need to be further explored. (3) While a large quantity of organic materials including small molecules and conjugated polymers have been developed, most of them were developed for the purpose of high-mobility OFET devices, and hence it is also important to explore more late-model OSCs specifically designed for chemical senor applications, with higher level sophistication and employ them in molecular design, so that accurate discrimination of analytes or stimuli can be achieved. (4) Suffering from bias-stress effect, OSCsbased devices can hardly achieve excellent operational stability, which remain as a challenge. (5) Another nonnegligible problem is that the strong binding event between analytes and OSC active layers tends to limit the recoverability of the sensor. (6) Strategies to solve the contradiction between sensitivity and stability need to be further investigated. (7) Additionally, the lack of sensing selectivity is a serious problem for OFET chemical sensors, due to the intrinsic sensing mechanism of OSCs. It is difficult to achieve high selectivity for sensors based on single OSC, and hence sensory arrays based on a series of different OSCs with specific properties to different analytes are required, in order to produce an instant and selective sensing output under conditions of substantial kinds of gases present at the same time. Efficacious and state-of-the-art strategies are still necessary to be brought out for selective sensing capacity. A sensor array with integrations of multiple OFETs can enable advanced applications. Different sensory properties are essential in promising research fields, such as bio-sensors with gaseous sensors[57] can provide valuable information on human body. (8) When it comes to portable and wearable sensor devices for commercial market, low working voltage and low power consumption will be needed, while most OFETs studied in the past need high operation voltage at tens or even nearly hundreds of volt. We firmly believe that, with the advancement in the OFET in the above areas, gas sensors based on OFETs will approach the topmost level of sensing capacity and make important contribution to the society in the near future.
